data.title: Match Group: A Clear Market Overreaction.
data.description:
Thesis

Match Group, Inc. (MTCH) portfolio is sufficiently diversified and dominant in the dating app industry to offset declining users across several of its apps. I believe the market is misunderstanding how popular Tinder is, its global reach and its penetration of younger users. Despite several catalysts for Tinder, the market is still pricing in a 27% annual decline over the next five years. Hinge is the fastest-growing dating app, and Bumble Inc. (BMBL) is beating Tinder in this race to the bottom. Still, with a troubled feedback loop and high CEO turnover, I believe the mispricing is clear and rate this a Buy.

Introduction

Match group owns well-known dating apps like Tinder, Hinge, Match.com, plus many others. The last time I counted, its Evergreen & Emerging segment had around 30 dating apps. I recommend taking a look at the names of some of these platforms as some are very unexpected to say the least.

Tinder's declining users have been concerning investors for a while now with paying user declining 10% y/y and revenue declining for the first time to $1.86 billion.

Even with 30+ Apps, 53% of revenue and 78% of OI come from Tinder. Hinge contributes about 20% of revenue and 16% of OI. So basically, Tinder and Hinge drive ~94% of Match Group's operating income. This says two things, first of all that its other two segments, E&E and MG Asia, despite comprising 17% and 8% of revenue, their margins are low enough that they contribute very little to the bottom line. Second, it explains why the market is so sensitive to Tinder's decline, which I'll show more clearly later in the DCF.

With a levered FCF margin of 24% and an ROA of 17.67%, it is clear the business is efficient and generating cash. Match Groups has had negative book value for about five years, mainly due to aggressive buybacks. In 2025, about 117% of UFCF was returned through buybacks and dividends. its has reduced its diluted share count by 10% over the past two years. with a net leverage of 3x and an interest coverage ratio of 6x, the debt looks manageable for now.

The fact of the matter is that Match group is the leader in the dating industry with more than 50% market share. Despite Tinder showing slowing growth and even negative growth this year, it is still the most popular dating app with around 25% market share. In fact Tinder, Hinge and Plenty of Fish are all owned by Match Group and together have around 50% market share.

Its profitability metrics tell a similar story with a gross margin of 72%, EBIT margin of 25%, net margin of 17.6% and a ROIC of 19%. These high margins and profitability metrics allows Match Group to be more resilient to top-line pressure.

Through my research, it became a recurring theme that Tinder is still the top app and that declining payers and revenue are the only metrics that show Tinder is declining. Don’t get me wrong, payers and revenue from Tinder are the most important metrics to consider but what I am getting at is that the market is overestimating Tinder’s decline and its impact on Match group.

Management

Something to be concerned about is the high CEO turnover since 2019. With four CEOs in eight years, none of them have been able to stop Tinder’s slowing growth and monetization. This is a high risk, as no CEO will be able to implement their vision in just two years. The main problem is that its shareholders have been very impatient with Tinder bleeding users. The new CEO, Spencer Rascoff has made significant changes to Match Group such as reducing its workforce by 13%, reducing management by 20%, centralizing tech and data among all its apps and generating $100 million in annual cost savings. All positive information, but Tinder payers and revenue continues to decline.

Before I explain why I think the market may be overestimating the bleeding, I want to quickly comment on Tinder as a service and its problems. As part of this research, I interviewed many students at the University of Arizona. I will later explain other insights I got but a recurring theme is that Tinder is plagued with bots and fake accounts. This, combined with the fact that Tinder has a reputation of being an app for hookups, creates a horrible app experience.

Opportunities

Even after being around for so many years, Tinder has still managed to appeal to the young generation with 35% of users being 18-24. It has the highest user penetration within the 18-24 and 25-34 age bracket.

When I interviewed students, Tinder was the most popular dating app with Bumble being a close second. What surprised me the most was that among students who have never used a dating app, the first app they would consider was Tinder. I think there is a massive opportunity in the fact that the young generation still use it even though it was launched when they were between 4-10 years old.

In this increasingly globalized world, it looks like Tinder is the first option for most countries when online dating and the hookup culture get adopted.

Another opportunity I see is that Bumble is actually in a worse situation than Tinder. Bumble’s paying users decreased 16% in Q3 2025 compared to an 8% decline for Tinder. Dating apps don't release user data only payer data but from the fact that Bumble has the same market share in the US at around 25%, and Tinder has double the amount of paying users at 8.8 million which means that Tinder is better at converting users into paying users. With this race to the bottom, although negative for Match Group's largest app, in general Hinge will benefit. I think this is the advantage that Match Group has, with such a diverse portfolio of apps, it is certain that Match Group will benefit.

I think the biggest opportunity however is again what the market is pricing Tinder will be in the future which I projected.

Valuation

My objective with this valuation was to determine what growth rates the market is pricing for Tinder and Hinge. To do this, I first of all assumed a WACC of 7%, which is an average of what I calculated and what I saw on different websites. I then broke down each of Match Groups segments and projected its RPP, Payer and operating income to project the revenue and operating income of each of the segments. I then made a DCF and incorporated the assumed projected revenue and operating income to arrive at a price. With conservative assumptions for the rest of the segments, I then calculated what Tinder's revenue growth will have to be to arrive at the current price of $30. Here are the results:

DCF:

The results show that with, in my opinion, realistic assumptions for the rest of the segments, the market is pricing in a 27% decline in Tinder revenue for the next 5 years. This is the main point of my thesis as it looks like the market has been chronically misunderstanding the slowing and now decreasing revenue from Tinder. Its diversified portfolio with the third largest dating app allows Match Group to be resistant to large declines in Tinder. With high adoption rates among emerging markets and among the youth populations it looks like it's very unlikely for Tinder to decrease so much in the next couple of years. In my view, that looks overly pessimistic. If I assume a more realistic 10% annual decline in Tinder paying users (instead of the market-implied path), my valuation increases to about $52 per share, implying ~73% upside. Now in the risk section I will try to point out the risk that the market may be also pricing in.

Risks

I think the main problem with a business model like Tinder is that barely anyone pays for these apps. Out of the 50 students I interviewed, only two had paid for a dating app, Tinder, and only for a brief period of time. Both of them told me it worked too well and didn’t even have the time to respond to every match. Any dating app has to balance its effectiveness and its monetization as each has the opposite effect. In a couple of interviews, students told me that they met their couple on dating apps and even someone’s sister met her husband on Tinder but I doubt any of them paid for it. Tinder relies on the hook up culture to receive compensation for unlimited swipes, which, in turn, worsens the app for people not looking for that (which is a big portion). With an intense dependency on networking effects, this makes Tinder be in a negative feedback loop where Tinder depends on people looking for a different experience than the majority, causing users to leave.

With the tumultuous CEO turnover it is hard for investors to understand the direction Match Group is taking and actually see changes. This combined with the fact that it has negative equity and a negative tangible book value of $2.7 billion makes it more risky. Leverage has only been increasing with $700 million added in 2025 while revenue stayed basically flat. In 2025, it returned to shareholders more than 100% of its FCF and management has committed to continue doing that. With cash growing, this suggests that debt may be helping fund aggressive capital returns (buybacks + dividends). This has me questioning the sustainability of its high share repurchase program and how responsibly management is using debt to support capital returns. With more than half of its total assets being goodwill and with many of its sectors declining in revenue, it is likely that an asset impairment will happen.

Conclusion

The way I see it is that the market is overestimating and overweighing Tinder’s declining revenue in a sector with intense networking effects. Despite the fact that paying for these services is a luxury barely anyone pays for, its international reach and popularity among the young generation is overlooked. The market could be pricing in a 27% decline every year or a 1% terminal decline and still Match Group’s portfolio will resist it. There have always been controversies with dating apps but I still believe that these will still be used and in an increasing amount of countries. Globalization has made hookup culture expand to other countries such as India, Indonesia and Japan and this trend will only continue. Tinder is the first app in mind for online dating and intense networking effects will make it hard for this to change. I rate this a Buy,

data.title: Microsoft: High-Margin Growth Points To A Premium Valuation
data.description:
Introduction

Capital markets haven't been kind to software companies lately; the sector that was once beloved for having near-zero marginal costs, recurring revenue, and an asset-light operational nature has recently witnessed massive drawdowns as investors fear that AI agents will replace most software functionality, leading to massive user churn, revenue declines, and margin compression. Even though these fears feel validated given that there is a swath of SaaS companies trading at massive multiples while providing marginal value to end consumers, the market has certainly overreacted on this one name that possesses a deep moat, high operational efficiency, double-digit top line growth, and enough capital and investments to benefit from this compute revolution, and that name is Microsoft Corporation (MSFT).

YTD, Microsoft's stock has declined by more than 20%, while its mega-cap peers only declined by single-digits. This drawdown is underserved for a company that has dominated the software industry for decades, proving management's tenacity and drive to maintain the innovative streak that enabled the firm to survive multiple tech revolutions. This time is no different, and if anything, to me it looks like the AI revolution will likely benefit incumbents rather than startups, given the upfront capital required for training and inference. This overreaction is giving investors that seek quality names an opportunity to benefit from MSFT's upside as the market corrects.

Among the Mag 7 names, Microsoft was one of the names that underperformed the SPDR® S&P 500 ETF Trust (SPY) and the Roundhill Magnificent Seven ETF (MAGS) on a 1-year performance, losing 5% of its value while MAGS and the SPY returned 16.59% and 15.07%, respectively. The outperformance of these ETFs was largely influenced by the massive rally of Alphabet (GOOG), which returned 72.33% YoY, outperforming both ETFs and its mega-cap peers.

Investment Thesis

My job as an analyst is not to just look at the firm's financial statements and do fundamental and comparable analysis to tell whether this could be a great investment or not; additionally, one should also do meta-analysis, meaning get a sense of how other market participants could be viewing the stock, because ultimately these are the people who deepen their wallets and hit the bid, resulting in a repricing. I have stated in my previous writings that in 2026 we are seeing a sector rotation, where capital is fleeing tech and going to less fashionable sectors like energy and materials. The core reason for this behavior is that most investors are starting to be wary of the promises that most tech names made trying to justify tight and often negative profit margins while trading at high multiples. AI adoption has also magnified the worry. Instead, investors are now lowering the risk exposure by loading capital to high-margin names that look insulated from the AI disruption.

The chart below shows the behavior difference between tech and the materials sector. For tech names, we are seeing EBITDA multiples trending down as EBITDA margins increase, highlighted by the slow decline in the green trend line, implying that investors would often pay more for low profitability as long as the multiples were justified by high topline growth. This is not the case in sectors like materials, where profitability actually matters, as it reflects the operational strength of the firm to return capital to its shareholders. This is highlighted by the slight upslope of the red trend line.

Digging in more into software names, this trend is even clearer. This reflects a historical behavior where investors over-indexed for growth and under-indexed for profitability. The rationale was that once software companies get to operate at a massive scale, it's easy to expand margins due to consumer lock-in. These assumptions are now in question, and it looks like companies with low margins will continue to witness price drops in the coming quarters.

Microsoft is insulated from this risk, in my opinion; it has one of the highest EBITDA margins in the sector but still trades below peers on EBITDA multiples (16.48 vs. the sector median of 17.51). The reason MSFT received a D- rating for valuation is due to its high price-to-sales multiple of 9.35 vs. the sector median of 3.12; this is not a preferred multiple to use for companies of Microsoft's scale. Ultimately, what matters to investors is the company's earnings power and how much of these earnings it returns to its shareholders.

Not surprisingly to me, most of these low-margin software stocks have actually performed badly YoY. This reflects the behavioral change I spoke about earlier; investors are rotating capital from low-margin to high-margin names. For Microsoft and other names with high EBITDA margins, the price decline was slightly moderate, while names like Rapid7 (RPD) with margins of 6% experienced an 80% drawdown.

Looking at the P/E vs EBIT margin chart below, we can see that it implies that, given the EBIT margin Microsoft returns, the stock is well rated at 24 P/E as it intersects the trend line; this should give us a margin of safety as it lessens the likelihood of the multiple to rerate even lower, and the upside potential is more likely as this multiple is lower than the sector median of 29.64, and given the expectation to see more capital flowing into high-margin names as a risk-off play.

Microsoft vs Mega Caps Fundamentals

Compared to mega-caps like Meta (META), Amazon (AMZN), and Alphabet (GOOGL), Microsoft is the only name that has consistently managed to expand operating margins at a consistent rate without massive fluctuation between quarters and now has the highest margin of all its mega peers. Since December 2020, Microsoft expanded its EBIT margin by 12 percentage points, from 35.74% to 47.09%, while Alphabet's margin remained flat at 31.57%.

Even when looking at top line growth, during the short-lived tech recession of 2022 and 2023, Microsoft didn't witness massive growth contractions and has managed to quickly recover back to the growth rate of the 2018 and 2019 periods, while all its mega caps contracted massively and still struggle to return to the previous rates. This shows that Microsoft not only has fundamentals superior to its sector peers but also to its mega-cap peers.

Earnings Results

Q2 2026 Income Statement

Looking at recent earnings results, revenue increased 17% to $81.28 billion, beating estimates by $993.68 million. This growth rate was driven by server and cloud services increasing by 31%, followed by M365 commercial and related cloud services increasing by 16%, and other services like gaming, Windows, and LinkedIn in aggregate increasing by 4%. Cost of revenue increased 19% to $25.98 billion, resulting in gross profits increasing 16% to $55.30 billion and landing margins at 68%, outperforming the sector margin, which is 48.85%. Operating expenses increased 5% to $17.02 billion, leading to operating income increasing 21% to $38.28 billion and landing EBIT margins at 59.36%, outperforming the sector margin, which is 6.62%. Pretax and net income increased 64% and 60% to $48.25 billion and $38.46 billion, respectively, bolstered by $9.97 billion from non-operating income, which landed EPS at $4.14 and an estimate beat by $0.22. Bear in mind that the firm now records capital gains from its investment, like in OpenAI (OPENAI), as miscellaneous income inflating pre-tax and net income.

Q2 2026 Cash Flow Statement

Operating cash flow also increased 60% to $35.76 billion, offset by a $9.63 billion cash outflow from working capital. Capital expenditures increased 89% to $29.88 billion, with 2/3 of the spending going to short-lived assets like GPUs and CPUs; this high expenditure led to FCF decreasing by 22% to $2.66 billion, landing FCF margins at 3.27%, underperforming the sector margin, which is 11.01%. This is the section of Microsoft's financials most investors are concerned about. I don't share the same concerns. Yes, if the firm were to reallocate these spendings to share repurchases and dividend payouts, the stock would easily rerate higher, but this would then put the company in a vulnerable position to get disrupted by firms that are willing to deepen their pockets and grow dominance in the AI space.

Q2 2026 Balance Sheet

And besides, it's not like Microsoft is using debt to build GPU chips and data centers; in fact, as illustrated by the state of its balance sheet, current debt decreased 8% to $4.8 billion, and long-term debt decreased 11% to $35.4 billion, while reserved cash increased 39% to $24.3 billion. The concerning item in Microsoft's assets is investments increasing 21% to $65.2 billion, making the current asset base more sensitive to mark-to-market repricing of these liquid assets the firm holds. If these assets are marked lower than the purchase price, we could see a decline in current assets. The same concern is true with long-term assets, as PP&E accounts for $261.1 billion and grew by 56% YoY. A majority of these assets are GPU and CPU chips with changing depreciation schedules and could be made obsolete by newer and more advanced GPU releases.

Valuation

Earlier in the article, I did point out charts that showed that Microsoft trades cheaply relative to its sector while returning more than average margins. Landing this point home, the firm also trades at a discount relative to its mega peers and the 5-year rolling historical median. I find these multiple unjustified given the consistent topline growth and margin expansion.

Risk

The first risk is the asset buildup I pointed to in the balance sheet section of this article. Given that depreciation schedules of GPUs and CPUs fluctuate drastically in response to newer releases. There's a small likelihood that these GPUs are losing value quickly, which will shorten the depreciation schedule, compressing margins, which would paint a dim picture of Microsoft fundamentals, impacting the valuation rerating.

The second risk has to do with the fact that 45% of Microsoft's backlog is sourced from OpenAI. Given the intensifying competition in the AI space coming from Google's Gemini and Anthropic, the chances of OpenAI losing its dominance and failing to deliver on Microsoft's obligations are increasing, and that could reduce Microsoft's future revenue expectation by $280 billion. One analyst pointed this risk out during the Q2 2026 earnings call, and management's response wasn't convincing to me, as it didn't lay out a coherent plan on how management is planning to reduce this exposure; instead, they just said the risk is lower relative to peers, which is not a good response.

Conclusion

Microsoft has experienced a massive selloff YTD due to the capital exodus that affected the broader tech and software sector; as a result, the firm now trades below its sector and mega peers on earnings multiple while continuing to grow top line by double digits and expanding margins at a consistent rate. This presents an appealing buying opportunity, as I estimate more capital will start flowing to high-margin companies as a risk to safety bet. I rate Microsoft a Buy.

Editor's Note: This article was submitted as part of Seeking Alpha's Top 2026 Long Idea investment competition, which runs through February 28. With cash prizes, this competition -- open to all analysts -- is one you don't want to miss. If you are interested in becoming an analyst and taking part in the competition, click here to find out more and submit your article today!

data.title: GenAI Fears Have Crushed Adobe, But Investors Are Wrong
data.description:
About eight months ago, in June 2025, I published my last article about Adobe (ADBE), and while my articles published between June 2022 and December 2024 were rated with a “Hold,” the June 2025 article was the first in which I was more bullish. And looking back, we can state that my “Hold” ratings were probably correct, and so far, Adobe has not been a great investment. When one would have bought the stock at the point the articles were published, one would have lost money.

In my last article, however, I wrote in the conclusion:

Although the stock was trading for cheaper prices in the past, this is the first time I would see Adobe as a cautious “Buy” instead of a “Hold” during my last articles. In the last three years, the fundamentals of Adobe improved, and therefore the stock is a “Buy” today, although it's trading for a slightly higher price than three years earlier when I rated the stock only as a "Hold."

This assessment and “Buy” rating was wrong – really wrong. Since my last article was published, Adobe has declined 40% and now the stock is trading more than 60% below its previous all-time high.

When looking back at the history of Adobe, we see several years of steep declines for the stock – and the current decline is not even the steepest. The stock suffered several drawdowns of 50% or more. Nevertheless, the stock seems very cheap at this point. I already rated the stock as a “Buy” in my last article, and now – with the stock trading 40% lower again – we take another look and argue why Adobe seems like a bargain, in my opinion. Software companies are under attack, but Adobe is not only reporting still great metrics - it's also trading for very low valuation multiples. Hence, many risks - including less consistent growth rates over the years - should already be reflected in the stock price, making it difficult to be bearish.

Extremely Low Valuation Multiples

We start by looking at the extremely low valuation multiples Adobe is trading for right now. Right now, Adobe is trading for 14.7 times earnings, which is already a low valuation multiple. We must go back to the years around 2010 to find similar low valuation multiples for Adobe, and it's clearly trading below the long-term average of 44.62.

When looking at the price free cash flow ratio, we get even more extreme numbers. At the time of writing, Adobe is trading for 10.8 times free cash flow, clearly below the long-term average of 27.56 and very close to the all-time low of 8.3. This is hinting towards an extreme bargain or a company that is clearly struggling to grow – to answer this question, we can start by looking at the last quarterly results.

Quarterly Results

On Dec. 10, 2025, Adobe reported fourth quarter and full-year results for its fiscal year 2025. We start by looking at full-year results. Total revenue increased from $21,505 million in fiscal 2024 to $23,769 million in fiscal 2025 – resulting in 10.5% year-over-year growth. Operating income increased 29.1% year-over-year from $6,741 million in fiscal 2024 to $8,706 million in fiscal 2025. And finally, diluted net income per share increased from $12.36 in fiscal 2024 to $16.70 in fiscal 2025 – resulting in 35.1% year-over-year growth.

Full-year results look pretty solid and don’t really match a P/FCF ratio close to 10. But full-year results might be misleading, and we also have to look at the last quarterly results to see whether growth rates are slowing down. In the fourth quarter of fiscal 2025, total revenue increased from $5,606 million in Q4/24 to $6,194 million in Q4/25 – resulting in 10.5% year-over-year growth. Operating income increased 15.5% year-over-year from $1,957 million in the same quarter last year to $2,261 million in this quarter. And diluted net income per share increased from $3.79 in Q4/24 to $4.45 in Q4/25 – resulting in 17.4% year-over-year growth for the bottom line.

In the next step, we can look at the guidance for fiscal 2026. Total revenue is expected to be between $25.90 billion and $26.10 billion – this would result in about 9.5% year-over-year growth. GAAP earnings per share are expected to be in a range of $17.90 to $18.10 – resulting in 7.8% year-over-year growth.

Metrics Still Great

So far, it does not seem like Adobe is really struggling. The company is still able to grow revenue in the high single digits (or maybe even double digits). When looking at quarterly revenue growth rates, we see revenue growth being pretty stable in the last few years, which is a good sign.

Aside from revenue growth, we can also look at gross margin and operating margin in the last few years. However, Adobe increased its margins, which is a good sign for the business.

Aside from margins improving in the last few years, we can also look at the return on invested capital – one of the most important metrics for any business. Of course, return on invested capital is fluctuating more than the company’s margins. Nevertheless, Adobe is reporting high return on invested capital on average – 24.6% in the last 10 years and 28.41% in the last five years. Additionally, we see RoIC accelerating in the recent past, which is also a good sign for the business.

Software Under Attack

A new technology is usually generating winners and losers and leading to major shifts in the economy. Right now, it seems to be the consensus that the business model of many software companies is under immense pressure or that some businesses might even go bankrupt – otherwise many valuation multiples can’t be explained.

And at first, we have to assume that GenAI applications can perform many of the tasks Adobe’s products are used for, quite well. However, that statement might be too superficial, and we will try to break it down by looking at the three reporting segments of Adobe.

The offerings bundled in the Publishing and Advertising segment might actually be at high risk. However, Adobe is generating only about $260 million in annual revenue from this segment, and it has already been declining in the past few years. Tasks like web application development or technical document publishing seem almost like perfect tasks for AI.

The second segment is Digital Experiences, which is responsible for $5.86 billion in revenue in fiscal 2025 and is growing about 9% year-over-year. For the applications offered in this business segment, there's also the risk of GenAI taking market share. Tasks like measuring customer experiences and providing analytics and reporting for advertisers, agencies, or publishers can certainly be replaced by other GenAI applications. However, these systems are usually deeply embedded in the company’s structure, and aspects like multi-channel coordination (due to different stakeholders) are hard to replace.

For the company’s third segment, Digital Media, the situation is similar. In fiscal 2025, it was generating $17.65 billion in revenue – resulting in a growth rate of 11.3% year-over-year. This segment offers applications to create, publish, and promote content, and it seems like GenAI is excelling at these tasks. However, when considering aspects like brand consistency (which is important for huge corporations), professional storytelling, or the fact that usually several different stakeholders are involved, it becomes questionable whether Adobe’s products can actually be replaced by other GenAI applications.

In my last article, I already wrote:

Adobe can generate huge opportunities to hold and grow customers if it is able to offer AI applications that are integrated within other programs in a way that is advantageous to users, which they can’t get anywhere else. If Adobe can include AI features, the switching costs might be high enough that customers will stay with Adobe – especially if other alternatives are similarly expensive.

The key for Adobe to defend itself against competitors is focusing on its core applications, which are hard to duplicate at this point and often deeply embedded in a company. The second and decisive step is to include GenAI functionality in its existing products. When Adobe is able to include these features, for which customers might switch to other products, into its products, it most likely can prevent the switching entirely.

Additionally, we should not ignore the steep learning curve most Adobe applications have. It could take hundreds of hours (or maybe even years) before somebody is at an expert level, and it remains questionable whether companies are willing to give up this knowledge to save a few bucks. The alternative (some GenAI application) has to offer similar functionality for a lower price to get companies to switch, and even if these applications are often more intuitive, it seems unlikely that customers would be willing to sacrifice the experience employees have in established software.

Finally, we also have to consider the possibility that we're all too optimistic at this point about AI and what it can do. One study called Remote Labor Index: Measuring AI Automation of Remote Work is painting a rather anticlimactic picture of GenAI and its abilities. Not only are all AI agents clearly below the human baseline when using an Elo score, but they're also able to achieve only a very small percentage of the tasks given.

Of course, replacing humans and replacing other software applications are two different things. Nevertheless, the study is showing that we might be too optimistic about GenAI right now.

Risks: Limited Upside, Less Consistency, and Improving AI Models

The biggest problem I see for Adobe (and some other software companies) is the limited upside and a declining consistency in its results. In the last decade (with most software companies switching to SaaS models), we saw high stability and consistency – especially for revenue growth. This was also part of the reason why software companies were trading for high valuation multiples, as investors usually reward predictability. It seems likely that a per-user, per-month licensing model will become rather obsolete in the years to come, and new metrics like consumption, outcomes, or organizational capability will determine the revenue of software companies (for example, pricing per token).

In such a scenario, revenue growth is still possible and also at similar rates, but we should expect the picture to be choppier – like it was before companies were switching to subscription models. And we should not expect growth rates to accelerate in any way, as software companies are rather in a defensive mode right now. However, limited upside potential for a company is not equivalent to declining revenue or even growth rates slowing down. Analysts are also remaining quite optimistic that Adobe will be able to grow in the high single digits or maybe even double digits.

A final risk for Adobe (and my bullish thesis) in the years to come is an accelerating improvement of AI models. When looking at the Epoch Capabilities Index for the different models, we still see them making progress and getting better, and the Frontier performance across different benchmarks is also showing improvements.

Recently, in an interview, Judea Pearl was also pointing out that the current transformer models we have used since 2017 and are still using (and which are responsible for the breakthroughs in the last nine years) can’t be scaled forever. But we don't know if scientists or the major AI players (especially Google) won't be able to make another leap forward and whether the Attention Is All You Need paper from 2017 won't be followed by another major breakthrough.

Growth Potential

And despite investors sending the stock into a steep decline, analysts are still optimistic that Adobe will grow at a high pace. When looking at earnings revision data, we see that analysts are getting a little more pessimistic and revising earnings expectations for the years to come. They're expecting revenue to continue growing at a high pace. In the years until fiscal 2035, revenue growth is expected at a CAGR of 8.7% in the years until fiscal 2035. And earnings per share are expected to grow with a CAGR of 10.45% until fiscal 2035.

One strategy Adobe can use right now is share buybacks. In the past few years, Adobe was mostly trading for high valuation multiples, making share buybacks rather ineffective. But with the stock trading for almost 10 times free cash flow, it can – and should use – its free cash flow on share buybacks.

In fiscal 2025, Adobe spent $11,756 million on share buybacks – more than the generated free cash flow and reduced the number of diluted shares outstanding from 443 million in Q4/24 to 417 million in Q4/25 – a decline of 5.9% year-over-year.

When using the free cash flow of the last four quarters ($9.7 billion), Adobe would be able to repurchase slightly above 9% of its shares outstanding, and this by itself would be enough to achieve analysts’ estimated growth rates for the years to come. Of course, this always depends on the stock price remaining at a low level, which seems unlikely if Adobe can continue to grow in the high single digits (or maybe even double digits).

Intrinsic Value Calculation

In the end, let’s calculate an intrinsic value for the stock to determine whether it is a good investment or not. As always, we're calculating with a discount rate of 10%, as this is the annual return we like to achieve at a minimum. Additionally, we calculate with 417 million diluted shares outstanding.

Now we could calculate with the free cash flow of the last four quarters, which was $9,718 million. However, when looking at the free cash flow margin, 40.9% in the last four quarters seems to be rather high and might be a bit too optimistic. Instead, we can calculate with the average free cash flow margin since the IPO, which was 31.9%. When taking the revenue for fiscal 2025, we get a free cash flow of $7,582 million that we're taking as a basis. Now let’s also be very cautious about the growth rates we use and assume only 5% growth for Adobe in the years to come. This leads to an intrinsic value of $363.65 for the stock, and Adobe is already trading below its intrinsic value at this point.

Additionally, we can calculate even with a more optimistic scenario. For free cash flow, we once again use the average free cash flow margin, but use the expected revenue for fiscal 2026. This leads to an expected free cash flow of $8,294 million, which we take as the basis for our calculation. Additionally, we can be a little more optimistic about growth rates in the years to come and calculate with 6% growth. Using these assumptions, we get an intrinsic value of $497.24, and Adobe would be deeply undervalued at this point.

Insider Activity

One final problem remains and that's something we should not ignore – insider activity. When assuming that Adobe is clearly a bargain at this point, it's a bit difficult to explain why insiders are only selling and nobody among management is buying the stock so far. If Adobe is really a bargain at this point and would also be perceived by management as a bargain, we should see some buying activity at this point. Of course, managers are not always great investors, and management might have many different reasons for not buying, but it's a piece of information we should also not ignore.

Conclusion

Adobe, similar to many other software companies, is certainly challenged by GenAI and insiders selling are another warning sign. However, aside from those two arguments, it's difficult to argue why Adobe should not be a “Buy” at this point. Looking at the metrics, the company is able to defend itself with high RoIC, increasing margins, and revenue still growing at a solid pace. Additionally, it remains questionable whether new AI applications are actually able to replace Adobe’s offerings for a cheaper price, and the company can defend itself by including GenAI applications in its software offerings.

data.title: Banco Santander: The Risk-Reward Proposition Has Not Improved Much Following Recent Events
data.description:
As I’ve covered in the recent past, I’m not particularly bullish on Banco Santander (SAN) following a strong share price rally over the past year, with the bank’s shares trading nowadays at a premium valuation to its historical values. As shown in the next graph, Santander’s valuation based on the price-to-book value (P/BV) is nowadays above 1.6x, being the highest level over the last decade.

This is not something specific to Santander, as other European banks are also trading at much higher multiples than in the past, as I’ve covered recently on HSBC Holdings Plc (HSBC). Santander is no exception and its P/BV multiple has increased significantly, from a bottom valuation of around 0.3-0.4x book value back in 2020 and just around 0.7x book value one year ago, to its current level of 1.63x book value.

Despite this strong re-rating of its shares over the last year, this was not supported by earnings growth, as Santander was pressured by lower rates in Europe over the past few quarters. Nevertheless, the impact was softer than feared some months ago, and earnings momentum has been positive in recent quarters supporting to some extent some re-rating of its shares.

Indeed, Santander has released at the beginning of February its 2025 earnings, with both revenue and earnings being above market expectations. Its revenues amounted to €62.4 billion in 2025, being flat compared to the previous year, as net interest income (NII) was pressured by lower rates in Europe and currency effect also had a negative impact on revenues, while fees were stronger and were able to offset weakness in NII.

Santander is one of the European banks more geared to interest rates, both due to its high reliance of NII on overall revenues (NII accounted for 73% of revenues in 2025), but also due to its higher exposure than average to variable-rate loans. This profile is obviously negative during a period of declining rates, making Santander’s NII weakness not a surprise and explains why NII declined by 3% YoY during 2025.

By business segment, this impacted mainly its retail banking segment, which is more exposed to loans, while other segments had a better performance and reported increasing revenues during last year. Specifically, payments were a bright area with revenues increasing to €6 billion, representing an increase of 17% YoY, driven by higher customer transaction activity, both related to credit cards and digital payments. The wealth segment also had a positive performance, a trend that was also visible for other peers, as rising capital markets and net inflows from customers boosted activity and fees during 2025.

Given this background, it’s not surprising to see that Santander’s fees increased by 5% YoY, to €13.6 billion in 2025, reaching a recover level. Other revenues, including trading gains, were up by 33% to nearly €3.4 billion, being also an important factor to offset weaker NII on total revenues.

Regarding costs, the bank achieved good cost control and reported operating expenses of €25.7 billion in 2025, down by 1% from the previous year, being an important contributor for improved efficiency. Santander’s cost-to-income ratio, a key measure of efficiency in the banking sector, was 44% (including corporate centre costs), being a good level of efficiency compared to other global banks, that usually have efficiency ratios between 50-60%.

On the asset quality front, Santander’s cost of risk ratio was stable at around 115 basis points (bps) implying provisions for loan losses of €12.4 billion in 2025 (an increase of just €100 million compared to the previous year). This shows that credit quality has not changed much over the past few quarters, being positive earnings stability.

Considering that Santander’s revenues, costs, and provisions for loan losses were almost unchanged during the last year, it’s somewhat surprising to see that its bottom-line increased by 12% YoY to €14.1 billion. This was largely driven by ‘other results’ that amounted to negative €3.4 billion in 2025, representing a decline of 30% YoY. These are related to impairment of assets, revaluations of financial assets, and other financial results that aren’t specifically related to the operating performance of the bank. This means Santander’s operating result was practically unchanged during 2025, with most of its earnings growth coming from less negative non-structural ‘other results’, that may not be recurring in future years.

This shows that Santander’s underlying growth prospects aren’t particularly impressive, a profile that the street seems to agree with, considering that both revenue and earnings estimates are expected to increase around low single-digits growth rates in 2026.

However, despite this relatively weak organic growth profile, Santander’s financial figures are expected to be impacted by several M&A operations that are pending, including the sale of its Polish unit and the acquisition of TSB Bank in England. Moreover, Santander has recently announced the acquisition of Webster Financial (WBS) for some $12.3 billion in a cash-and-stock deal in the U.S., being the largest acquisition from a European bank in the country over the last two decades.

As Santander was expected to have some excess capital when it completes the sale of the Polish unit, with only part of proceeds being recycled on TSB Bank, it has capacity to grow in other regions and has decided to expand its presence in the U.S.

This acquisition was valued at about 2x tangible book value, which is not particularly cheap, as Santander seems to be buying at the top of the cycle. However, as Santander U.S. is a segment that is largely exposed to consumer finance, namely auto finance, this acquisition allows it to change its profile in the U.S. and become much more exposure to retail and commercial banking. Indeed, within the group, the U.S. operation had a different profile compared to other regions that are usually more exposed to retail and commercial banking, something that was somewhat odd as Santander has a conservative risk profile and auto finance is not particularly a core business in other regions.

Therefore, I see this acquisition as a positive step on a strategic point of view for its U.S. operation, leading to a lower risk profile and a more sustainable operation over the long term. This is also visible on some key financial indicators, such as the cost of risk that is expected to be reduced by some 30 bps for the combined bank and the loans-to-deposits that should decline from 109% to 100% following the consolidation of Webster.

Moreover, Santander expects to extract about €800 million of annual cost synergies from this acquisition, leading to improved profitability of the combined bank over the next few years and EPS accretion of 7-8% by 2028.

With this acquisition Santander will have a much more balanced loan book profile in the U.S., being in my opinion one of the most attractive factors for this acquisition. As shown in the next graph, the combined entity will have less loan exposure to consumer finance and a higher to weight to commercial & industrial (C&I) loans, as Webster is largely exposed to C&I and commercial real estate (CRE) loans and has a much lower cost of risk ratio than Santander’s current U.S. operations.

Beyond announcing earnings and the acquisition of Webster, Santander has also performed an investor day recently, presenting new financial target and business outlook for the next three years. Its strategy is not expected to change much in the near future, aiming to grow its business through customer growth while cutting costs and improving efficiency at the same time, namely by using technology and AI.

Regarding its financial targets, Santander aims to reach a net profit above €20 billion by 2028 and a return on tangible equity (RoTE) ratio above 20% (vs. 16.3% in 2025), being somewhat aggressive targets in my opinion. Management seems confident that it can achieve business growth over the next three years and continue to improve efficiency to a level around 36% by 2028, being key for higher profitability ahead. As AI is rapidly improving and is making several tasks easily automated, I believe the bank can cut costs significantly over the coming years. Additionally, the consolidation of TSB and Webster should generate important revenue and cost synergies. This means Santander may be able to achieve its financial targets by 2028, but execution is key during this period and is something that investors should monitor closely over the next few quarters and years.

Regarding capital, Santander maintained its target of having a CET1 ratio of at least 13%, which seems acceptable considering the bank’s business profile largely geared to retail and commercial banking. As the bank’s capital ratio is close to its target, the bank has plenty of room to return capital to shareholders ahead, but Santander didn’t change its distribution policy much for the coming years. It expects to return around 50% of annual earnings to shareholders, with about 35% being through dividends and 15% through share buybacks. This seems to be conservative, and Santander could have been more aggressive in my opinion, as there is not much need to retain capital over the next few years.

Conclusion

Banco Santander’s operating performance during 2025 was not fantastic, with revenues and operating profits practically unchanged from the previous year, while the bottom line benefited from lower losses on less relevant financial figures. Despite that, its valuation measured by the P/BV multiple more than doubled during the last year to the highest level over the last decade, as investors have pushed bank stocks to all-time highs in recent months. While Santander is taking good steps to improve its business profile, such as the acquisition of Webster, and its financial targets for 2028 show confidence on business growth and profitability ahead, I think Santander’s current premium valuation is high and makes its risk-reward proposition not much attractive for long-term investors.

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

data.title: Target: I'm Waiting For Q4 Results Before Making A Move (Downgrade)
data.description:
In my last article on Target Corporation (TGT) (check it here), I mentioned that although I didn't visit any stores when I went to the U.S. (unlike Walmart (WMT), for example), the numbers alone had convinced me that the market was too pessimistic and that Target actually deserved a second look.

At the time, the financials weren't super interesting, but the P/E was close to single digits, practically a distressed asset. Now, TGT stock has gained a re-rating from the market; it has been given this second chance, and in a few months the stock has risen about 35%.

And for me, that's enough to be a little more cautious. It's not a bad case or one without potential, but we're talking about a Target that is no longer a “deep value,” where you were paid in dividends to wait for the turnaround to happen.

Target's Last Quarter Was Just Ok

When I saw that TGT stock was rising, I looked at the Q3 earnings (which came out a few months ago); I expected more. I thought the market had seen some transition point, and while that may be the case (I'll explain why in the next section), the financials themselves are a little disappointing.

Sales continued to fall, by about 1.5%, and I expected comp sales to be “less bad.” Note in the chart below that Q3 comp sales were worse than Q2, with Q3 declining by almost 3%.

I think there was a reasonable explanation: the spending on discretionary items is still poor, but at least Target managed to grow in other segments such as beverages and toys. Macroeconomically speaking, it makes sense that the average American continues to spend at Walmart and Costco (COST), and with higher inflation, it becomes more difficult to spend at Target on these more “superfluous” items.

Returning to last quarter's performance, Target’s operating margin, excluding some non-recurring items, was reasonable, only slightly worse than Q3 2024, and the gross margin also remained stable, a positive point in my view. Also, Target did not have to give up margin to maintain some growing segments, such as running a super promotion on beverages that did well in the quarter. There were even some markdowns and other pressures, but nothing to worry about.

Why Could This Be The Turning Point For Target?

Even with this mixed quarter, it's not that hard to understand why the market is treating this as a pivot point. Q3 earnings were the last quarter for the former CEO, who handed over the reins to Michael Fiddelke and mentioned in the earnings call that he supports the entire team “as they make changes to the way we work.”

Basically, it's a management transition, and this has already come with some interesting initiatives. Remember I said that beverages grew well? It was about 7% YoY, and this is related to these initiatives.

The new CEO mentioned that he is adopting AI-enabled insights to increase the levels of newness at Target. More than that, he mentioned “3 key priorities”: merchandising authority, the digital experience, and efficiency:

“Michael Fiddelke, Executive VP & COO, identified three key priorities: “solidify our design-led merchandising authority... offer a more consistently elevated experience across our stores and digital platforms... more fully use technology to improve our speed, guest experience and efficiency throughout the business.” He confirmed a recent headquarters restructuring eliminated about 1,800 roles, “a difficult but necessary step forward.”

Well, we are already seeing this happen. In the image below, it is noteworthy that digital comp sales continued to grow even with consolidated comp sales falling, not to mention that in assortment highlights, Target got it right with products and positioning of trends such as Halloween, college, beverages, etc. Consider that if the execution had really been poor, and Target had not been able to ride these trends, the performance would have been even worse.

And I believe this will be crucial in Q4, which will be reported on March 3rd. Obviously, I don't think anyone is expecting high, positive comp sales. In fact, the guidance is for declining revenue, and the market expects a -1.4% drop in revenue. But if the current management proves that it has at least managed to stem this, I think it could be bullish for Target.

Again, I'm not talking about aggressively growing the top line, but showing, for example, that it managed to decline revenue by “only” 0.5%, showing that digital and “newness” initiatives are really bringing good results.

Other than that, I believe that guidance for Q1 may be even more important. Even if turnarounds take time, I think Q1 could be the real turning point, where the CEO points out that with these initiatives, revenue may stop bleeding, and that with efficiency gains, margins may already improve, which would lead to at least a slight increase in the bottom line.

This would open up a lot of room for Target's prospects to return to health, and then shareholders could once again envision shareholder value compounding, even if at a slow pace.

TGT Stock: Not A Bargain Anymore

And TGT's valuation is still not bad. The forward P/E is 15x, and its average over the last 5 years is 17x, so we are still talking about a certain discount. The same is true for metrics such as EV-to-Sales and EV-to-EBITDA. The discount here is close to -20%.

And even though the dividend yield has fallen because TGT stock has risen, the market expects a forward dividend yield of close to 4%, which makes some sense.

If Target manages to grow its EPS a little, which is likely with the new initiatives and some buybacks, it is already easy to estimate an EPS of around $7.50. If it distributes something close to 60%, the dividend per share goes to $4.50, and with the stock at $110, this gives us exactly a 4% dividend yield.

It's far from bad, but in the last article, if the dividend per share were $4, the dividend yield would already be 4.7%. It's now clear that to deliver a higher shareholder yield, Target needs to execute; it needs to really deliver a little more than the “minimum.”

Do I think Target will deliver? Yes, it seems likely to me, which is why I am not giving it a sell rating. But besides no longer being the bargain it once was, the execution risks still exist. Everything I mentioned seems very positive to me—initiatives, new management—but we need to see how it all plays out.

And with Q4 earnings coming up, I prefer to be a little more cautious and have a little more data to work with to see if Target can really reach its turning point or if it will take a little longer.

Bottom Line

Target is a case that still deserves some attention, but I don't think the risk-reward ratio is that attractive anymore. And patience in these more complex cases, in my view, is welcome. Maybe the stock will rise a little more if Q4 earnings are much better than the market expects, but I think it makes more sense to wait and see how this actually plays out over the next 1 or 2 quarters.

Therefore, my rating for TGT stock is now a Hold.

data.title: FS KKR Capital: No Compelling Growth Catalysts To Slow NAV Decay
data.description:
Overview

With interest rates remaining elevated, many Business Development Companies have continued to struggle over the last year. However, FS KKR Capital Corp (FSK) has unfortunately suffered from a much larger pullback compared to the majority of peer BDCs out here. When I previously covered FSK, I issued a sell rating due to the poor earnings growth, questionable dividend coverage, and declining NAV. FSK has recently reported its Q4 earnings, which prompted me to revisit the BDC's appeal and value proposition at this time. Despite already trading near all-time lows, I believe that there may be additional downside risks for investors to consider.

Looking at the performance over the last twelve months, we can see that FSK's share price continues to experience severe erosion and has declined by more than 51%. Even when including all distributions that were paid out to shareholders, the total return still sits at a loss of 33.6% over the same time frame. Following the declines, FSK's starting dividend yield has ballooned up to ~16.2%. However, this follows a large dividend reduction that was implemented over the last quarter as earnings have struggled to support payouts.

There continue to be structural flaws within FSK's portfolio setup that limit returns. FSK has struggled to allocate a meaningful level of capital towards new investments, and I worry about the underwriting on the new loans that are implemented. Although FSK's non-accruals don't appear that high, they still sit considerably higher than peers. Overall, there just don't seem to be any compelling catalysts for growth in the near term.

Q4 Results

According to the latest portfolio overview, FSK has investments at a fair value of $13B, which is a decline from the prior fair value of $13.4B. Unlike traditional equities, FSK doesn't rely on the earnings growth of its assets. Instead, the BDC invests in a portfolio of different debt securities that produce income from a borrower's ability to repay loans. FSK maintains a high level of diversity across its investment types but leans most heavily on first lien senior secured loans. The portfolio's updated breakdown by investment type is as follows:

  • First Lien Senior Secured Loans: 57.8%.
  • Joint Venture (Credit Opportunities Partner): 15.1%.
  • Asset Based Finance: 13%.
  • Preferred Equity: 6.1%.
  • Second Lien Senior Secured Loans: 4.2%.
  • Equity/Other: 2.4%.
  • Subordinated Debt: 1%.
  • Other Senior Secured Debt: 0.4%.

Expanding on this diversity, FSK also provides exposure to a wide range of sectors. I believe that one of the challenges comes from FSK's primary allocation to software & service investments at 16.4% of the portfolio. As the tech sector continues to sell off due to threats around AI, perhaps FSK's own positions are experiencing challenges in the current environment. This is followed by an allocation to commercial & professional services and health care equipment, which accounts for 13.3% and 12.8% of assets, respectively.

FSK just reported its Q4 earnings, and the results continue to disappoint. Most notably, adjusted net investment income amounted to $0.52 per share, which missed expectations by $0.02 and was a decline from the prior year's adjusted net investment income of $0.66 per share. Total investment income landed at $348M for the quarter, where the largest contributor to the decline is the reduction in interest income received from borrowers. For instance, interest income landed at $201M, which was a large reduction from the prior year's interest income of $257M.

Similarly, FSK suffered from a large net realized loss of $244M during the quarter, which continues to demonstrate how higher rates may be suppressing the growth of its positions. Over the last twelve months, FSK hasn't really been able to lock in any meaningful net realized gains, so this issue may go beyond the higher interest rates. I believe this ultimately comes down to the actual positions management selected since there are plenty of other BDCs that are capable of capturing realized gains on a consistent basis. For instance, I previously covered Gladstone Investment (GAIN), which captured net realized gains and experienced unrealized appreciation in its positions. Over the last year, we can see how these two BDCs have performed much differently in share price.

On a more positive note, FSK was able to reduce its operating expenses to help partially offset its earnings. For instance, total operating expenses landed at $195M, which was a decline from the prior year's total operating expenses of $213M. The largest contributor to the lower expenses was the reduction in interest expense down to $110M and a reduction in incentive fees to $28M.

Unfortunately, FSK can certainly improve from a balance sheet perspective. FSK now has cash and equivalents of $181M, but this is a reduction from the prior year's cash and equivalents balance of $278M. Similarly, FSK's total debt rose up to $7.6B, which caused the debt-to-equity ratio to rise to 1.22x. As FSK becomes more dependent on debt to fuel growth, it is imperative that the new investments lead to higher earnings, or else these losses will continue to compound over time.

Valuation & Risks

At the time of my last coverage, FSK had fallen to a deep discount to NAV of 30.74%. Following the decline after this most recent earnings report, the current discount to NAV has widened to 36.24%, and I anticipate that it will erode past the 40% discount level as well. Referring to the red line on the graph below, we can see that FSK now trades at one of the deepest discount to NAV levels over the last decade, with the outlier being the dip experienced during the pandemic. This deep discount is a clear indication of the underlying challenges that the portfolio continues to face.

One of the primary issues that I have with FSK is the lack of capital being allocated towards new investments. The portfolio continues to bleed its NAV because exits and repayments outpace the new investment capital. For instance, FSK was able to allocate $1.09B towards new investment purchases during the quarter. However, this was offset by $1.33B in sales and redemptions, which ultimately resulted in a negative net investment activity of $236M. While this was technically offset by net sales in the joint venture investments of $528M, this isn't really enough to drive the needle forward for growth.

The struggle to allocate capital towards new investments is why the net investment income has not improved over the last year. Even worse, this sort of issue means that the portfolio is shrinking over time, which leads to NAV decay. FSK's NAV has struggled to regain any sort of meaningful positive momentum over the last year as sales and redemptions outpace new investments. For reference, here are the quarter-end NAV amounts:

  • Q4 2024: $23.64 per share.
  • Q1 2025: $23.37 per share.
  • Q2 2025: $21.93 per share.
  • Q3 2025: $21.99 per share.
  • Q4 2025: $20.89 per share.

From a risk perspective, FSK's non-accrual rate now sits at 3.4% of fair portfolio value. While these may not seem that much higher than other BDC peers, I still worry about the long-term structure of the portfolio. Just as a quick reference point, here are the non-accrual rates for some peer BDCs that have recently reported earnings.

  • Gladstone Capital (GLAD): 1.6% non-accrual rate at fair portfolio value.
  • Ares Capital (ARCC): 1.2% non-accrual rate at fair portfolio value.
  • Blue Owl Capital (OBDC): 1.1% non-accrual rate at fair portfolio value.

The failure to grow net investment income may be attributed to the macro environment, but I worry about the actual quality of management's underwriting on its loans. Higher interest rates mean that it is more costly for businesses to take on debt financing, which typically leads to fewer high quality deals in the market. So although FSK has technically continued to allocate some capital towards new investments, there's always the risk that these new investments aren't the highest quality deals out there. This can lead to underlying earnings growth in the future, even if interest rates continue to decline throughout 2026.

So while the higher dividend yield may be enticing right now, I want to put emphasis on the fact that FSK has been one of the worst performing BDCs out there over the last year. If you still want exposure to the BDC sector and a double-digit yield, consider choosing one of the BDC ETFs available to investors that can reduce the risk of the sector.

  • VanEck BDC Income ETF (BIZD): 12.5% dividend yield.
  • Putnam BDC Income ETF (PBDC): 11.4% dividend yield.

Dividend Reduction

As of the latest declared quarterly distribution of $0.45 per share, the current dividend yield sits around 16.2% at the time of this writing. This represents a massive 29.7% cut to the prior distribution of $0.64 per share. However, we already knew this was coming since management announced a targeted 10% distribution at the time of its prior earnings report. Additionally, adjusted net investment income landed at $0.52 per share for the quarter, which indicates that the earnings are now supporting the base distributions.

While FSK has done a great job at keeping payouts consistent in the past, I am glad that this cut was finally implemented. A lower payout will reduce the pressure for FSK to create a high level of income and can free up some cash that can be reallocated towards different growth initiatives or debt reduction. Although it may take some quarters for these shifts to materialize into higher earnings, I believe that this should ultimately slow the rate at which FSK's share price declines going forward.

Management also had a sizable amount of spillover income still, so there is a small supplemental distribution of $0.03 that is being paid over the next quarter. Therefore, there may continue to be additional supplemental distributions paid out over the remainder of the year so that management can shed its remaining spillover income.

Lastly, distributions received from FSK do not offer any tax efficiency for investors. Since distributions are being supported by interest income, the distributions are classified as ordinary dividends, which have the greatest tax consequences for investors. Therefore, FSK would be best utilized within a tax-advantaged account for investors that want to limit their tax liabilities.

Takeaway

In conclusion, FSK remains a sell at this time. Even though the share price has experienced a rapid pullback from its prior levels, the downside risk remains as the NAV trends downward and the net investment income has not grown. As management struggles to allocate capital towards new investment activity, there are limited growth catalysts to look forward to. As long as interest rates remain elevated, the overall health of the portfolio may continue to decline. FSK is also more reliant on debt to fuel growth, supported by the higher debt-to-equity ratio. On the bright side, the lower distribution may help improve performance over the long term as it frees up some capital.

Alphatec Holdings, Inc. or "ATEC" is a medical technology company that designs, develops, and advances technologies for the surgical treatment of spinal disorders.

In recent years, ATEC has successfully grown market share and outperformed sales expectations on a regular basis.

Unfortunately, growth has come at a price, as evidenced by persistently negative free cash flow in recent years. Please note that numbers have been adjusted for acquisitions:

However, things have been moving in the right direction over the course of 2025 as also evidenced by this week's fourth quarter and full year financial results:

ATEC generated $7.7 million in free cash flow and ended the year with $160.8 million in cash and cash equivalents and $691.7 million in funded debt. The company's $60 million revolving credit facility remained undrawn.

On the conference call, management guided for continued growth, albeit at a more measured pace:

Please note that ATEC has outperformed initial sales guidance for seven consecutive years now. Should this pattern persist, 2026 growth might be well north of 20% again.

Once again, Alphatec Holdings outperformed growth expectations in 2025. In addition, the company delivered vastly improved profitability and cash flow.

While expectations for moderately lower growth in 2026 have caused shares to drop in recent weeks, investors should remember the company's long-standing pattern of outperforming sales expectations.

With management projecting an almost 50% increase in Adjusted EBITDA this year, I would consider the recent selloff a buying opportunity.

As a result, I am reiterating my "Buy" rating on the shares while increasing my price target from $18.00 to $20.00.

data.title: Verizon's Growth Inflection: Up 22% This Year. Here's What's Next
